THIS CRIMINAL MISC. CASE HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON
07.01.2019, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING:

Crl.MC.No.8654/2018 2019/KERIO89
-: 26
ORDER

The petitioner herein is the 2" accused in
C.C.48/2011 of the Special Court (SPE/CBI),
Thiruvananthapuram, which is a prosecution brought
by the CBI. After the examination of the
prosecution witnesses, the accused were called upon
to enter on defence. As required under Section 243
Cr.P.C., the petitioner submitted a list of
witnesses, and requested the court to summon those
witnesses. The list submitted by him contains four
witnesses, and the list also explains the purpose
for which each witness is sought to be examined. Of
the four witnesses cited by the petitioner, two are
serving or retired bank officials, and the 4
witness is a Chartered Accountant. The application
filed by him as Crl.M.P.180/2018 was opposed by the
CBI on the ground that examination of those
witnesses unnecessarily would only delay the
process, and defeat the ends of justice.

Crl.MC.No.8654/2018 2019/KER/689
-: Bre

2. After hearing both sides, the learned trial
Judge allowed examination of three of the defence
witnesses, but disallowed the request for
examination of the 4° witness as defence witness.
Aggrieved by that part of the order dated
13.12.2018, disallowing examination of the Ath
defence witness, the 2" accused has come up before
this Court under Section 482 Cr.P.C.

3. On hearing both sides, and on a perusal of
the impugned order, and also the list of witnesses
submitted by the petitioner before the trial court,
I find that the object for which the 4 witness is
sought to be examined can be achieved even
otherwise, and that the request was rightly
disallowed by the trial court. The 4 witness cited
by the petitioner is a Chartered Accountant, and the
purpose of his examination as a defence witness is
to explain the banking procedure, including the
procedure for sanctioning different types of loans.
This procedure is covered by the circulars and

Crl.MC.No.8654/2018 2019/KER/689
-: Are

instructions issued by the bank authorities, and the
Reserve Bank of India. The prosecution has already
examined some bank officials. No doubt, the
petitioner and the other accused must have
thoroughly cross examined those witnesses on all
issues, including the banking procedure, and also
the procedure for sanctioning different types of
loans. Any way, two more witnesses are being
examined on the defence side also as bank officials.
Tf at all the petitioner wants to bring out any
clarification as regards banking procedure, that can
be brought out through the examination of the
witnesses 1 and 2 cited by him, and of course, he
must have brought out the required materials through
the cross examination of the prosecution witnesses
also.

4. A Chartered Accountant is not expected to
explain the banking procedure. He cannot be said to
be an expert on the field. He can, of course,
competently say about auditing and accounting.

Crl.MC.No.8654/2018 2019/KER/689
-: 5 re
Banking procedure, or the procedural formalities
regarding different banking transactions will have
to be explained by the competent persons, including
bank officials. Such things cannot be brought out
through a Chartered Accountant. That is why, the
trial court disallowed the request to examine a
chartered accountant for explaining banking
procedure. I find that it was rightly done by the
trial court. Any way, if at all the petitioner
wants to bring out some clarification on the
relevant issues or aspects as regards banking
procedure or the sanctioning of loans, he can very
well bring it through the defence witnesses cited by
him. If at all he has omitted to put the necessary
questions to the prosecution witnesses on the point,
those witnesses can very well be recalled, if felt
or found absolutely necessary. This cannot be done
as of right. If such a request comes before the
trial court, the depositions given by the bank
officials on the side of the prosecution will have

Crl.MC.No.8654/2018 2019/KER/689
-: Gre
to be examined carefully and thoroughly by the trial
court, and see whether those aspects sought to be
clarified are already covered by the depositions
given by the witnesses in cross examination. Tf
those aspects are not already covered by the
deposition given by the prosecution witnesses, and
if the defence witnesses 1 and 2 are not able to
explain such procedure with competence, the trial
court can think of allowing the request to recall
the prosecution witnesses under Section 311 Cr.P.C.
With these observations, this Crl.M.c. is
disposed of.
Sd/-

P.UBAID

JUDGE
